title: 112_hr2686
content: The "Children First Act of 2011" excludes child care from TANF assistance and increases funding for child care. The "Children First Act of 2011" excludes child care from TANF assistance and increases funding for child care by $3.4 billion for fiscal year 2012, $3.6 billion for fiscal year 2013, and $3.6 billion for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2021. Additionally, the act addresses the applicability of state or local health and safety standards to other TANF child care spending. Section 402(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to require certification of procedures to ensure child care providers comply with state or local health and safety standards. This is in relation to the availability of child care for parents required to work. SEC. 5. AVAILABILITY OF CHILD CARE FOR PARENTS REQUIRED TO WORK. Amends Section 407(e)(2) of the Social Security Act to include "or other individual with custody" after "parent" and changes the age limit from "6" to "13". SEC. 6. APPLICATION OF CHILD CARE AND DEVELOPMENT BLOCK GRANT ACT OF 1990 REPORTING RULES TO TANF FUNDS EXPENDED FOR CHILD CARE. Section 411(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include reporting rules for funds expended on child care, regardless of transfer to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. This amendment exempts such funds from the reporting requirements for a fiscal quarter. The Social Security Act is amended to include reporting rules for funds spent on child care, exempting them from reporting requirements for a fiscal quarter. The Social Security Act is amended to include reporting rules for funds spent on child care, exempting them from reporting requirements for a fiscal quarter. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on October 1, 2011, and apply to payments under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act for calendar quarters starting on or after that date. Section 6 amendments will be effective on October 1, 2012. States requiring legislation to comply with the Act's amendments will not be considered non-compliant solely for that reason. The Act's amendments will take effect on October 1, 2011, and apply to payments under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act for calendar quarters starting on or after that date. States with a 2-year legislative session will be deemed to have separate regular sessions for compliance purposes.
